titleStmt.title: More victories lately obtained in Ireland. The successfull and victorious proceedings of the noble and faithfull Lord Inchiquin, Lord President of Munster, against the rebels there. Certified in three letters : two of them under his Lordships own hand, directed to the Honourable William Lenthall Esquire, Speaker to the honourable House of Commons : the third to an honourable member of the said House, from an eminent officer in the army.
titleStmt.author: Inchiquin, Murrough O'Brien, Earl of, 1614-1674.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: MORE VICTORIES Lately obtained In IRELAND.
THE Succe≈øsfull and victorious Proceedings of the noble and faithfull Lord INCHIQUIN, Lord Pre≈øident of Mun≈øter, again≈øt the Rebels there.

Certified IN THREE LETTERS: Two of them under his Lord≈øhips own hand, directed to the Honourable William Lenthall E≈øquire, Speaker to the Honourable Hou≈øe of Commons: The third to an Honourable Member of the ≈øaid Hou≈øe, from an eminent Officer in the ARMY.
LONDON, Printed for Robert Bo≈øtock at the Kings Head in Paul's Church-yard. 1647.

div.head: A Letter from the Lord of Inchiquin Lord Pre≈øident of Mun≈øter, directed to William Lenthall E≈øquire, Speaker of the Honourable Hou≈øe of COMMONS.
div.p:
BEing con≈øtrained by divers nece≈ø≈øities of the ≈øouldiers to retire about five weeks ≈øithence out of the field, where I had been in the Rebels quarters of the County of Limerick, before I could look into the County of Tipperary, I did after ≈øome ≈øhort refre≈øhment, and the be≈øt (though but mean) provi≈øion wihch I could make for the ≈øouldier, apply my ≈øelf and this Army forthwith again into the field; and being for want of Oxen and other carriages unable to draw forth any Artillery, or to carry any larger proportion of bread then what the ≈øouldiers knap≈øacks would contain, I marched with the Army into this County, which I entered upon on Saturday the third of this in≈øtant; and having taken ≈øeverall Ca≈øtles therein, to the number of ten or twelve, putting to the ≈øword the warders of ≈øuch places as ≈øtood in oppo≈øition to the Armie, I pa≈ø≈øed over the River Shewer not far from the Ca≈øtle of Cahir, an ancient and eminet hold of the Rebels, environed with two branches of that River, which was ob≈øerved to be, in all appearance, of that ≈øtrength, as it was both by them, and by the Officers of this Army e≈øteemed impregnable: notwith≈øtanding which, the importance of the place being ≈øeriou≈øly con≈øidered by us, we were occa≈øioned to make an attempt upon it by this accident; One
of our hor≈øemen being plundering neer the Town, was by ≈øome of the Rebels wounded, and carried a pri≈øoner into the Ca≈øtle, from whence he was admitted to ≈øend for a Chirurgeon into our Quarters to dre≈ø≈øe his wounds, of which we made this u≈øe; One Colonel James Heppe≈øly, who had formerly ≈øerved the King, and was (upon ≈øome a≈ø≈øurance given me by a friend, of his doing ≈øervice) admitted to come into our Quarters, being an ingenuous per≈øon skilled in Chirurgery, and in Fortifications, took upon him to go under a di≈øgui≈øe into the Ca≈øtle, and to dre≈ø≈øe the wounded Trooper; which accordingly he did with ≈øo great caution and circum≈øpection, as that he di≈øcovered perfectly the condition of the Ca≈øtle in each re≈øpect, the weakne≈ø≈øe of the Ward, and e≈øpecially ≈øome defects in the wall of the outward Bawne, which rendered it a≈ø≈øiultable by our men, the taking whereof would probably induce the ≈øurrender of the Ca≈øtle, which he collected from the ob≈øerved timorou≈øne≈ø≈øe of the Warders; which ≈øorted to ≈øo good purpo≈øe, as that falling on the place defective with a party led on by Colonel Heppe≈øly him≈øelf, wee carried that outward Bawne, and ≈øome out-Turrets by ≈øtorm, and within a few hours after had the Ca≈øtle ≈øurrendered unto us on quarter onely for life, though upon entry of it wee found that the ≈øame was by no force of ours to be reduced, if the defendants had not been by divine providence deprived of any courage to oppo≈øe us.

The place is ju≈øtly looked upon by this Armie as the mo≈øt important in the whole Province, being of that ≈øtrength as not to be taken from us ≈øo long as we have victuall to ≈øupport a Gari≈øon therein, whereby a pa≈ø≈øe is kept open for us to make daily incur≈øions into this Country, which hath been a principall contributary to the Rebels Army.

To the performance of which Service the Souldier was enabled with no other food then the roots under, and corn above the ground (all their cattell being driven away before us out of our reach) of the later whereof wee had great and abundant ≈øtore, ≈øo as we have burned in this County above 20000 pounds worth, whereof there could be no u≈øe-made through want of hand-mils, (for which I have often and earne≈øtly written) the water-mils being for the mo≈øt part either burned or de≈øerted.

From Cahir we marched this in≈øtant to the City of Ca≈øhell, formerly the Metropolitan Sea of this Province, where the Citizens and Inhabitants amazed at the reducing of Cahir, left open the gates, and fled to the Cathedrall, a large and ≈øpacious Pile ≈øeated upon a Rock neer the walls of the Town, and of late very much fortified, and at pre≈øent fully manned with divers Companies of the Rebels, which will render any attempts wee ≈øhall make upon it very difficult; not with≈øtanding which, we determine, by Gods a≈ø≈øi≈øtance, to leave no meant una≈ø≈øayed for the reducing thereof: after which we de≈øigne „Äà‚óä„Äâ upon the Town of Fethard, an eminent walled Town; and from thence to march unto Clonmel, to reduce which wee have yet no great hopes, in regard wee under≈øtand that place to be very regularly fortified, and ≈øtrongly manned, ≈øo as without Artillery there can be no ≈øeizable attempt made upon it. But if it ≈øhall plea≈øe God to ble≈ø≈øe us with ≈øucce≈ø≈øe on that place, wee may confidently a≈ø≈øert the Parliaments intere≈øts in this Province to be high, and the Rebels mean and incon≈øiderable. Sir, The Gentry of this County by the reducing of the≈øe places, and the burning of their corn, begin to make ≈øure that they may be admitted to a Contribution; which ≈øhall be imbraced, ≈øo far as may conduce to the better carrying on of the War, and ≈øupporting this Armie, and advancing (as my zeal and duty obliges me) of the Parliament Service, for which I have no other means then this of keeping the Field; from whence if I ≈øhall be driven to our Gari≈øons by the violence of the weather, or by an overpowerfull Armie, I am utterly ignorant how the Armie now abroad, or the ≈øick men and others in Gari≈øon may be pre≈øerved from ≈øtarving, without ≈øea≈øonable ≈øupplyes from the Honourable Hou≈øes, to who≈øe Service I have faithfully devoted my ≈øelf, remaining

div.head: Another Letter of his Lord≈øhips, of the ≈øame date.
div.p: THe Occurrences here are ≈øeldom worthy to be a trouble to you: And though you perceive by tho≈øe that accompany this Letter, that the Lord hath been plea≈øed to go along with our proceedings in an extraordinary manner this Summer, yet certainly if our want of means and Carriages were con≈øidered, there would in rea≈øon have been but a ≈ølender expectation of our endeavours; and now the nakedne≈ø≈øe of the Souldiers grows ≈øo powerful and a≈ø≈øi≈øtance to our other wants, that we ≈øhall ≈øuddenly be di≈øabled to contend with them, if clothes be not ≈øpeedily ≈øent thence for our relief: And therefore I am to reque≈øt your favour in the behalf of this Army (that have undergone much hard≈øhip, and are mo≈øt willing to ≈øacrifice their lives in the Parliaments ≈øervice) now de≈øtitute of Clothes and Shoes, in≈øomuch as within the≈øe few nights of cold weather ≈øome of the Souldiers have died of cold, which mu≈øt needs be a great di≈øcouragement to the re≈øt. And as I take it to be my part humbly to repre≈øent it to that honourable Hou≈øe, ≈øo I am confident that by your good means the ≈øame may the more ≈øea≈øonably be removed; wherein your a≈ø≈øi≈øtance may contribute much to the ≈øervice of the State, and ≈øhall much oblige

div.head: A Letter from an Officer of quality in the Parliaments Army in Mun≈øter, to a worthy Member of the Hou≈øe of Commons.
div.p:
FRom Ca≈øtlegrace I gave you an account of the proceedings of the Army ≈øince my Lord of Inchiquin's la≈øt march abroad into the Field, where he hath been very active and ≈øucce≈ø≈øeful, ble≈ø≈øed be God. He burnt the Country round about, and afterwards fell on the out-wall or Bawne of the Ca≈øtle of Cahir, upon ≈øome intelligence that his Lord≈øhip gained of a defect in ≈øome part of it: in the gaining whereof, Colonel Courteney, Colonel Heppe≈øley, and divers others, behaved them≈øelves gallantly, ≈øo as with the lo≈ø≈øe of one Captain Ba≈ø≈øe, and three or four Souldiers, we got the Bawne, and made our approaches under the Ca≈øtle-gates, and within a few hours after, got the Ca≈øtle upon quarter for life onely, upon a Parley by them de≈øired. This Ca≈øtle was heretofore be≈øieged twelve weeks by the old Earl of E≈ø≈øex, then Lord Lieutenant of Ireland, with the Queens Army in tho≈øe Wars, and is conceived to be one of the ≈øtronge≈øt Holds in all Mun≈øter, being al≈øo ≈øeated on an I≈øland on the River Shewer, upon which River the ≈øtrong walled town of Clo ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ el, and many other ≈øtrong Ca≈øtles are ≈øituated; and it opens a pa≈ø≈øage to the County of Kilkenny and tho≈øe parts. My Lord hath placed in Gari≈øon the Regiment of Colonel Francis Roe, which was ≈øent over by the Parliament with the Lord Li≈øle, at Cahir. From hence my Lord commanded us to march immediately to the City of Ca≈øhel, ≈øix large miles di≈øtant, where the ≈øupreme Councel of the Rebels lately held their meetings; and found that the ≈øudden and unexpected taking of Gahir Ca≈øtle, and the burning of the Country, had ≈øo affrighted the ≈øouldiers and inhabitants, that the ≈øouldiers had quitted the City, left open the gates, and were gotten into the Cathedral Church ≈øtanding on a high Rock next the City, which they had fortified formerly;
in all, ≈øix entire Companies, and about two hundred Towns-men, and ≈øome women; who being ≈øummoned by my Lord the fir≈øt night, ≈øtood upon high terms: the next day his Lord≈øhip offered them to march with their Arms, which they refu≈øed, but afterwards would have accepted of it; but my Lord having drawn out the men ready, and conceiving the work to fea≈øible, commanded the men to fall on, which they did re≈øolutely and bravely, and in little more then an hours time the Church was taken, and all the men put to the ≈øword, except the Governour (Lieutenant. Col. Butler) who is dangerou≈øly wounded; Major Butler, who was Maior of the Town, his ≈øon, and ≈øome few others who were taken pri≈øoners. Tho≈øe ≈ølain were above four hundred: and ≈øuch was the goodne≈ø≈øe of God to us, that we lo≈øt but one Captain and eight men in this ≈øervice; but indeed we have neer an hundred hurt. The Rebels are in a cruel fright, whereof my Lord intends to make the be≈øt u≈øe he can, and is now ≈øending to ≈øummon Fitherd, a ≈øtrong walled Town five or ≈øix miles hence, and within fourteen miles of the City of Kilkenny, which hath been the ne≈øt and magazine of the chiefe≈øt of the Rebels. Ble≈ø≈øed be the Lord for this good ≈øucce≈ø≈øe on this noble Lord and this Army, who are very entire, and very ready to do as much as men in their ca≈øe can do for the ≈øervice of the Parliament.

I thought good hereby to give you notice of what hath pa≈øt ≈øince my Lord made his di≈øpatch, being now three days ago, and withal to let you know that we have now received notice that the Lord Taaff with about five thou≈øand Rebels (who dare not give us battel) have done us ≈øome mi≈øchief about Cork in our ab≈øence, in burning the hou≈øes and corn about Garrigroghan, from whence they went to Awneboy. ≈øix miles we≈øtward, and burnt al≈øo there, and got ≈øome money to ≈øpare other parts; and now they lie about Bandon, and threaten it. What my Lord and the Councel will do hereupon, is not yet known to us; but without doubt they will do what they conceive be≈øt for the Service, as far forth as God ≈øhall enable them: And if we be ≈øo happie as to overtake them, I tru≈øt I ≈øhall ≈øend you a further Relation by the next, which you will have cau≈øe to ble≈ø≈øe God for. And ≈øo I re≈øt,
